I have had some dining experience in some of the more popular restaurants with near 100 year old history.  So, I do know when I come across a nice French restaurant.   Les Deux Gamins is certainly NOT in the group !    I had the Duck Confit, I had a bad aftertaste in my mouth after.. all night long; The folks don't know how to cook duck.   I have had much better experience having a duck made fresh in Paris.I don't quite understand there are so many reviews of Les Deux Gamins.   Is very disappointing, I won't go back, and I won't recommend anyone going there.

great service and excellent food. nice ambiance, the place is quite rustic and chic. My kids love their food. They had hanger beef steak and my husband had lamb shank. I took the duck confit which is just perfect. I would definitely come back again!

Very tasty food and friendly service. The waitress were very accommodating to us , there were no more seats left outside and they managed to get another table outside to sit my family of 4. Their re Sangria was soo good, along with their specials

If you can dine al fresco, simply charming.Get the hanger steak.If looking for white wine, try their white malbec  - no idea there was such a thing.The tiny kitchen downstairs reminded me of my line cook days - Organized chaos with, what I assume was the sous, keeping the the train on the tracks.Had a great time and an excellent meal.

The food we ordered were very delicious, and the service was kind enough. Even though we were not able to speak French at all, the servers constantly tried to explain about the menu while we were choosing our dishes. Especially, 'Lamb shank' was great - it doesn't smell weird (I am kinda sensitive to smell of lamb) at all, the combination between meshed potato and BBQ sauce goes well perfectly, and the portion is very generous as well. The free dessert - creme brulee for today - we got from the redeem coupon was the perfect match for the espresso.

The lamb shank is wonderful, with gorgeous mashed potato. The homemade sauce is a bit sour and sweet and more. This sauce makes the dish fresh and super tasty. It's a big dish, too. I can't even finished it. My friends order duck leg, also very good, with their homemade cherry sauce on the side of the dish. Perfect dinner.

I just walked out. First of all, limited menu. They served a rib eye special steak for 2 peoples, when I ask to order same order, the waitress said that the item is sold out and had to be a minimum of 3 peoples. While right in front of me 2 peoples ordered the rib eye and was being served the item, as I asked - she took me for an idiot. When I got up to leave - she said is there something wrong ? I replied, yes this is the worst customer service and I will not be giving my business to someone who can not serve me food properly. She didn't even apologize, instead she replied "but I ordered your apps" - ridiculous ! The plates are a decent prices running between 25-30$ a plate, I expect an exquisite service. There are plenty of better restaurants in Montreal with better service and better food. NEVER would I give them my business
Wonderful meal, fantastic steak and foie gras with very attentive and excellent service.

Friendly service, reservation wasn't necessary on a Sunday night. Food was tasty. Shared app special of salmon mousse, and we ordered the lamb shank and veg tagletelle dish as mains. All were delicious. Checked in on yelp to get a free mini creme brulee dessert, which did not disappoint.Cute resto, great for a date or dinner with friends. Not the swiftest of service, but it's also nice not to feel rushed. Thought it was a BYOW location but it isn't.

I really liked this place. We booked the thanksgiving diner pre fix. The meal was great and so was the wine pairing. The only thing that was missing was the cranberry sauce. The chef made a beet and apple sauce which was good but not the same. Everything else was terrific. I especially liked the pumpkin pie which was made in a tart crust and was especially thin.

I don't know why, but each of the three times I've been here, Les Deux Gamins always seems to primarily attract two types of people - your stereotypical Anglophones and Chinese tourists (yes, I would know because I can understand their Mandarin). Of course, the occasional Francophone hops in here and there, but not enough to remove the "hidden tourist-y" vibe it gives off. Nonetheless, it is arguably the cheapest French bistro in the city, so I don't want to completely invalidate it because it does serve up some quality eats.I decided to order the goat cheese salad for my appetizer and the seasonal risotto for my main course. Before that all came out, however, I was served a bread basket that contained your stereotypical baguette and butter. It was still warm and fresh, though, so I ate it happily. The goat cheese salad had enough greens to fulfill at least half of one's daily recommended total, as well as the perfect touch of sweetness from the candied walnuts. Of course, the hot goat cheese tasted sublime when combined with everything else, and I used the leftovers to spread on the remaining bread slices. Next came the risotto, which was arguably the highlight of the night. I believe that it was served with enoki mushrooms and cheese (it was hard to see but I inferred from the texture). Wow. Everything harmonized in my mouth to produce the perfect combination of bite from the risotto, the almost meaty quality of the mushrooms, and just the right amount of cheese. I had to control myself not to eat it too fast because it was just that great.For dessert, I used the Yelp promo for free dessert upon check in, and I got a small crème brûlée-type dish. It had a nice sound when I cracked the top to reveal the creamy bottom. The hard caramel top provided a nutty contrast to the smoothness of the cream, which was very nice and a perfect way to top off a delicious meal.Overall, Les Deux Gamins provides great food for the price they offer and is one of the tourist traps (in my mind since they don't really appear on Montréal tourist must-go-to lists) that is actually worth visiting if you can get past the somewhat annoyingly nitpicky Anglophones that tend to hover around the establishment. However, I did get charged for water this time since I was asked by the waiter if I wanted mineral or sparkling water, and I was slightly confused because I always received normal water without question; hence I thought mineral water was its equivalence. One bottle cost about six dollars added to my total bill so that was kind of a yikes moment. The only reason why I'm not giving 4 stars is because the waiter did state that it was his first night working, and I'm usually lenient on first-time mistakes. So in case that happens to anyone reading this, just ask for normal water instead, i guess.
The service was slow, but that didn't take away from the over experience. The food was delicious from the cold soup to the poached cod. Our server was wonderful. Bravo!
Nice atmosphere and great food. Staff was very nice and spoke english which was very helpful.I would recommend stopping by if you can.

This place was surprisingly good. It is a touristy restaurant and I'm not sure how often it is frequented by the real Montrealers. Having lived here for about a year, however, I would say that it's just as good as the other local gems of the city.The service was spotty. We ordered the warm goat cheese salad, duck confit and sea bass as our main entrees. All super delicious and rich. For dessert we had their bread pudding, which was essentially a deconstructed pain au chocolat. Very delicious.
Great food! The foie gras torchon was one of the best I ever had, and the duck was fantastic. Definitely recommend!

Last dinner in Montreal and I'm glad I can say it was a good one. Right when I walked in I felt like we were back in Paris. The smell of delicious food to the round tables and wicker chairs, it was already off to a good start. They seemed realllly busy so it took a little bit to get our orders in, but that's almost always a good sign, right? We started with the onion soup and weren't disappointed. It was flavorful and just hot enough (I hate it when they bring it out warm and it cools so quickly that by the middle of eating it you've got cold giant lumps of cheese). Then we got steak frites- steak was tender and fries were nice thin and crispy. Also got the duck confit which was also tender and paired well with the accompanied veggies. The only thing we weren't a fan of was the brownie for dessert, it was more cakey than preferred but it was free (with check in!) so can't complain.
A solid choice. The meat and cheese board alone is worth it. Excellent deserts and a helpful staff.

Les Deux Gamins never fails you!! Classic French courses, made with impressive precision and consistency throughout. The menu is very reasonably priced, which goes for the wine menu as well. Try the Chablis - it's amazing!!

One of the best meals we had while we were in Montreal. That lamb shank...oh my. Let me tell ya, I was holding myself back from picking it up and gnawing the meat right off of the bone. So tender and flavorful. And it was HUGE! I mean, look at that pic! Of course, I finished every last bite. (Gotta pad that muffin top.) b. enjoyed her duck confit, which was also cooked very well and came in a large portion too. The sauce made a nice pairing - complemented the meat without overpowering it. But in the end, I think my lamb shank KO'ed b's duck, hands down. Our appetizer, the foie gras, was okay, nothing special. But we also had no idea what "au torchon" meant when we ordered it so maybe our expectations were off. We probably would have done better with the beef tartare, which looked pretty good from the looks of the table next to us, but we were pretty meat-ed out by that point in our trip.Service was friendly enough. When we arrived early for dinner, I asked our waiter whether we could be seated on the second floor in front of the open balcony. In typical French form, he responded with a short but polite, "No, is impossible." This tickled us. Oh, if only I had a French accent.
Very courteous staff.  Homemade bread...out of this world.French Onion Soup - excellent...rich onion taste.Smoked Salmon over potato salad........yummy!Wait staff and host staff very courteous.

Great food - great service!  We really enjoyed the Discovery Board, escargots and the foie gras for starters.  Our table also had duck and steak tartare for mains.  Server suggested a great wine pairing.  Thanks!

Our first night in Montreal and our server was Axel. He was very kind to Americans with little to no French. The atmosphere was perfect and the weather was beautiful. I ordered the Confit de Canard and it was amazing!! Never had duck until tonight and I want it every night now. Crime Brûlée was very good as well. Very good and decent prices pick for our first dinner in the wonderful city!

Good food but feel ripped-off.  Our first night in Montreal and made reservations based on Yelp reviews.  It was a short subway ride from our hotel.  I ordered the shirt steak and my wife the duck.  We split a onion soup.  Good exceeded our expections, was great and prices reasonable.When the bill  came, I asked the waiter/host if they accepted US dollars and was told certainly.  I paid the bill with US dollars and received change in Canadian--dollar for dollar.  They kept the 25%+ exchange rate, so we  overpaid by 25%.Back at our hotel, I  asked if this was normal, and was told definitely not.PS  The restaurant offered to refund the overpayment

Firs time being here and would love to come back during summer time! Because they have a semi patio on the second level and also can open up the garage door. The atmosphere was very intimate and full of French style of poster and also music in the background, not too loud. It is a great place to come with the love ones. We started with octopus bruschetta. The flavor was slightly sweet with the fresh greens and the beer marinated octopus. The whole dish was a great start. But one down side of it was it only came with one toast so it is not sharable.  We also had French onion soup and it was good but a little bit too salty:P The food is prepared with excellent plating and We were party of four so we fortunate to try all their classic entrees. Duck,steak, fish, lamb... all four of them had very different flavor and texture. At the end I had a mini creme brûlée. It was very tasty. The whole experience was well-blended French cuisine. Definitely will recommend others to come!
Good food, service and environment. Butcher's cut was perfectly made and portions were generous.
Very rude The entire restaurant was empty. The receptionist told us they are full for the night

Very good food.Nice ambiance in the restaurant and on the terrace. Loved the french onion soup and the Foie Gras. Beef hanger steak was stunning and my friends really loved the lamb and duck.Friendly and attentive service.We will definitely come back.

Food was amazing!We arrived at Montreal and I made a reservation because we are a party of six (kids 8, 10 and 13 and three adults). We stayed at the Westin and walked the 25 minute walk to the restaurant. It was very quiet at 5:30 when we arrived, but the restaurant was full by the time we left at 8 PM. Our kids were certainly underdressed, but but nobody made an issue of it. I would definitely try to look at least organized if not nice.Food was amazing. We had soup of the day, cheese plate and escargot as an appetizer. As a family we enjoyed the lamb, the duck confit, the hanger steak and the pasta (can't remember dish name).  Everything was delicious! Our waiter was sweet as well.  Definitely would return!
Extremely disappointed. My husband and I ordered the french onion soup, there was barely any a soup. We also ordered the hanger steak and it was not good. It was served cold and simply not good.

It was delicious. Service is classic laid back French, attentive, and friendly. The lamb shank was the highlight and it's a must have. Get it! Lovely outdoor seating. Got a free desert for checking in. This was our "fancy" dinner. It did not disappoint.

I have been meaning to come to Les Deux Gamins forever, but normally I try to avoid the touristy scene that is Prince Arthur, plus I was waiting for winter to be over so that I could terrasse it up. Came here with a group last night and even though we were a bit of a rowdy group, the service was absolutely spot on.The evening started off with a Zou Bisou cocktail which was mixed to perfection: vodka, Chambord, jus de pomme and topped with a yummy blackberry; anything that has a connection to Mad Men, I'm so drinking it! I tried the tapas menu: 3 items for 10 bucks (how awesome is that?) I had the tartare de saumon which was incredible, the rillette de salmon and the best bruchetta that I've ever had, yum yum. The portions were a good size and everything was fresh and done to perfection. Any restaurant where the owners come out to talk to the table and actually care what you think of the place gets a thumbs up from me.I can only imagine how great this place is going to be in the summer with the huge windows that will open onto the street, overlooking the fountain. It feels like you've been transported to Paris while dining here and the added fact that they don't gauge you on the wine prices means that I will most definitely be back.

Lovely restaurant; I always take my parents here whenever they visit Montreal. The food is amazing, especially if you like duck confit. The ambiance is comfortable and cute; perfect for a date or group dinner. The service is very helpful, even at busier times they make sure you're well taken care of. The location is situated along a pedestrian type street within a neighbourhood, where you could peruse around after dinner. There's usually parking near the school and along the road. Love this place!

It is a cozy place. Good for group and romantic dinner. I rarely eat the French Onion Soup but this one was very good. So cheesy but not salty. The only disappointment is that too much bread and not enough soup. Otherwise, this would be perfect. The lamb shank entree was delicious. The BBQ sauce was not too heavy or sticky and the lamb doesn't taste much of foul odor at all. The duck confit was cooked perfectly with the meat.
This is a hidden gem.  The decor is very low key, hole in the wall. However, when visiting from NY with two friends, the service was excellent and the food was amazing. I got the Lamb Shank!

This place is really very good. Thanks, Yelpers. It actually wasn't our first choice, but while other restaurants could not accommodate our largish party on short notice, Les Deux Gamins could and we're glad for it.We were able to make a reasonable dent in the not-too-large menu of bistro faves.Duck ravioli was nicely done, served in a brown butter sauce. The  house salad was fresh and generous.Fish of the day was Mahi-Mahi;  the whole fish lightly grilled and served with rice. Almost an Asian take on the dish. Very very good, we left nothing but bones. Onion soup was a fine rendition, although probably best to share as it is too rich for one.Warm chèvre and walnut salad with honey was simple, but outstanding. Needed nothing moreLamb shank in Whiskey BBQ sauce was tender, tasty and presented very well. Again, nothing left but the bone.Crème brûlée for dessert was perfect;  custard at the perfect consistency with a think, crisp brûlée layer on top.Service was remarkably efficient, particularly considering how few staff there were. Our server did double-duty in the kitchen; I saw here there with a blowtorch finishing a crème brûlée.We will definitively be back the next time we are in town.Go.

A truly great experience!!  The food, service, wine, and atmosphere were all top notch!!  Found it because of Yelp and turned out to be in an awesome area that we probably would not have stumbled upon otherwise

What an absolutely wonderful and charming restaurant. My partner and I went to Les Deux Gamins on the last night of our vacation to Montreal, which we picked over L'Express. So happy about that decision!The restaurant was cozy and quiet, with exceptional service and tasty food. We had a bottle of Champagne to celebrate the end of our trip, and it was fantastic (and very well priced). Our courses were perfectly spaced, so that we never felt rushed or looking for our food. We had the French Onion soup (so delicious! I'm still thinking about it today), beef tartare, foie gras torchon and the Hanger steak. Everything was delicious. Our server was very kind and made us feel right at home, even though we are from out-of-town.

The best food in Montreal, the waiter was excellent and attentive. Food was magnifique. Got the duck leg, tartare beef, and the lamb shank. Can't go wrong with any one of them. Will definitely come back if I'm in the area again. 5 stars

We arrived here on a Thursday evening. The ambiance was very nice. Let's cut to the chase. We ordered french onion soup, foie gras, beef tartar, and duck confit. Presentation was lovely. The only dish I enjoyed was the duck confit which was fall off the bone good and the veggies complimented it very well. Now as for the beef tartar, I ordered it because I saw so many people mention it in the reviews. It lacked seasoning. Not what I thought it would be. French onions soup was generic. I tried foie gras for the first time here and didn't like it. I'm not deducting points for that however because maybe I won't like foie gras anywhere else either. Service was great but nothing stood out here that will bring me back.

We wanted some good French food while visiting Montreal, and were very happy with the food and service we received at Les Deux Gamins. I started off with the French Onion soup which was great - crusty top, rich broth, mmmm.... I then ordered the Braised Lamb Shank, which was fall-off-the-bone tender and delicious and the shallot sauce was amazing. We also tried a couple of French wines that were excellent - and the overall price of the meal was relatively affordable. It felt like a classic French restaurant in a small, intimate space - the service was excellent. I highly recommend if you are looking for some good French soup and cuisine.

This restaurant had great potential. It is very large, possibly three floors but only three or four tables were seated on a Monday night at 7. The waitstaff could not have been kinder. The bread was served warm, but the accompanied butter was a prepackaged tab. Having a house-made spread or even a tableside olive oil would have been a nice touch. The French onion soup was very nicely executed. For entree, the beef tartare was very nice but lacked flavor. It was definitely better once I added salt, but again, it needed a special touch. We didn't have dessert but there are a few on the menu. Overall, it was a solid choice for good food. While it didn't wow us, it did allow us to leave full and satisfied.

This is a tough place to review because we had to leave shortly after arriving.  We really enjoyed the French Onion Soup (amazing) but had to get our entrees to go.  It is a very cute restaurant although very warm inside.  Very friendly staff and hope to make it here again.

This charming French Bistro was my favorite of numerous restaurants we enjoyed while visiting Montreal. They serve unpretentious and delicious food. The service is very attentive and my request for a slight diversion from the menu was kindly accommodated. I enjoyed a delicious and fresh salad and a the Duck Confit!  So freaking good. You will want to make it your lover.  Lots of bread and butter was served before and with our dinner and the French red wine, recommended by our server, was exceptional.  For dessert, Hubby and I split a luscious Crème brûlée.I love the restaurant name which translates as "Two Round Kids".  If I ate here every night, I would definitely be a round kid.  Depending on where you are staying, you may have to take the Metro to this neighborhood that is a mix of shopping and dining.

We came here for dinner as there was a write up about how great this place is.  For all the hype, we felt this place was over rated.  Our server was very nice, but the food didn't meet our expectations, and it was a bit more expensive than other places that have similar menus.  We had a few apps, the goat cheese salad, escargots, foie grois, and french onion soup. The apps were pretty good. The bread was also great here. It just took a while to get it. The entrees did take a long time to get served, and were not as great as we expected.  We got the lamb shank, beef tartar and steak frites. The beef tartar was just ok, it had a runny egg on it which is great, but it runs all over the place. The steak looked like it was cook perfectly, but it was tough to eat (ordered medium rare).  We weren't happy especially having similar dishes at L'Express the night before.We had a single profiterole for dessert which was great.Overall, not worth the hype.

Overall, a great experience.  We had a very nice table upstairs near the fireplace and felt like we were back in time.  The French music was perfect.  I started with the foie gras which was very good.  For dinner, our party had the lamb shank, the goat cheese salad and the steak frites.  The lamb shank was fantastic and highly recommended.  The goat salad comes with a terrine of goat cheese, and was also highly rated.  The steak was sadly less than mediocre.  It was undercooked, and even after being reheated it was not good quality.  Dinner was saved by the fantastic service, and they brought us  free profiteroles which were excellent.  I would go back.

After a ten hour drive, the dinner was exquisite. The ambiance made us feel like two young drunk lovers in France serenaded by a local musician on the street. The beef tartare and French onion soup were delicious. The duck confit was finger-lickingly good. The cheese and cold cut plate was well prepared. Definitely something to try if you're a fan of cheese! We had the complementary creme brûlée offered by yelp and it was surprisingly very good as well. Very classic and not too sweet. Overall, we had a very lovely experience. The waiter recommended some very good wine to pair with our food and dessert. We feel that all the dishes complemented each other well and you can't go wrong at this restaurant. The servers were very kind and prompt. We will definitely come back again when we're in Montreal!

omgosh so yum!!!Like everything we ate here was delicious and free wifi!Came here with 5 ladies ready for dinner. We got the escargots, sweet potato fries, the pate and for entrees we got the risotto which had clams, salmon and I got the duck confit.OMGOSH it was exactly what I was looking for and delicious. I slowly took my time to eat it and we all shared portions of our foods with each other. We also got a free dessert through our yelp check-in (THANKS YELP!) and enjoyed the creme brulee :)I'd def return for the duck!!!

This was our last and easily our best dinner in Montreal. Showed up late and were seated immediately exactly where we wanted - next to the fireplace- where our waiter immediately started a fire for us. We enjoyed a strong cocktail that was recommended to us. The bread was the only disappointing part; it was cold and may have been as good as any supermarket bread, but was still tasty. Water never went empty.My wife ordered a dish similar to beef stew with some clearly French twists in its flavors. It was moist, tender and delicious. I ordered duck confit with Mac and cheese which was the BEST Mac and Cheese I think I ever had - creamy, cheesy, a nice baked crust and the duck was also a generous portion of delicious, non-greasy, fantastically flavored duck. Unfortunately we had no room for dessert- a true shame. With 1 cocktail, 2 entrees and tax, our bill was $68 Canadian before a well earned tip.The atmosphere was warm, romantic, intimate, just truly a fantastic experience.Overall, if I could give more stars, I would; this may be my favorite dining experience of all time.

SO SO SO DELICIOUS.A few friends and I dined on the lovely patio here and had some wonderful food. The service was friendly and relaxed, and the patio was the perfect place to sit and watch people walk by.Now the food:Duck Confit: Absolutely fabulous. This came with a nice salad and deep fried potato rounds, which were possibly cooked in duck fat, they were so good. The duck itself was perfect. Just... perfect. Crispy, fatty, tender and full of flavour. This is the duck confit I dream about at night.Steak tartar starter: Chunky pieces of raw steak, heavy on the coriander (which I like). Not the best I've had, but pretty good. Flank steak: The Hubster's meal. The frites were amazing, but the steak was chewy and so-so.Everyone else seemed to enjoy their meals, but we were too busy with conversation for me to grill them about it.I will definitely come back here again and recommend it highly to anyone who's in Montreal.Also, they have check-in offers!
Great place, friendly staff, remarkable food! Very reasonable prices too! Yoki from yuka, tartar meat and veal cheeks were made to perfection!

Came here for a birthday dinner. We were comfortably seated at a table with plenty of room between each other, as well as a comfortable distance from other tables. I have never been to France, but the decor and ambience had me feeling like I was. I ordered the flank steak, medium rare, and shared a beef tartare with the table. The steak was fine but nothing stood out to make it different from other steaks I have ordered, though I have to note it was beautifully cooked. I really enjoyed the tartare as it was light and fresh. Overall it was an enjoyable evening. Good ambiance, good food, and good service.

The food here not only tasted really good, but it was also presented really well. I especially remember the escargot I had. I do feel, however, that this restaurant is a little overpriced for the quality of ambiance and food. I didn't fully enjoy all the food I had, and the interior, especially towards the direction of the bathroom, was slightly sub-par for a restaurant of this level. But overall, I enjoyed my dinner, and the waiters were extremely attentive and efficient.

Excellent food and service. Got here about 45 minutes before closing and the kitchen stayed open for us. The French onion soup was just okay, the chèvre and honey stew was delicious, as was the hanger steak. The wine was good too. We would eat here again.

Really unfortunate circumstance where great food was overshadowed by absolutely abysmal service and poor communication. My girlfriend took me to this well-reviewed authentic French restaurant (God bless you babe, you were a wonderful date!), and I was really looking forward to good ol' Quebecan food. We had ordered the cheese platter as appetizer and shared both the salmon tartare and the duck confit with scalloped potatoes. The cheese platter was decent (albeit a little small) and the salmon tartare was well plated and fresh.Unfortunately, that was when the night took a turn for the worst. When the server brought me my dish, it was a completely different dish than I had ordered [tuna salad]. I politely waited as he scrambled to get the correct dish. By the time he brought the dish, it was a pulled pork dish over salad, also not what I had ordered. By this time, I had waited over 20 minutes while my girlfriend's dish had become cold and the sweet potato fries soggy. Finally, after 30 minutes of waiting, I finally received the correct dish, and it was amazing! But still had a bitter aftertaste from half an hour of waiting and no real apologizes from the staff.At the end of the dinner, we were not given a real explanation on why my meal was inaccurately delivered 3 times in a roll. And worst of all, they still charged me for the dish [although they took $2 off the price] and had the courage to ask for a 15% tip. If it weren't for my girlfriend politely asking me to stay calm, I would have ranted out loud for the horrible service.The food may have been good, but the service was so atrocious that I will NEVER come back.ps: We weren't the only people who got the wrong orders; there were at least 2 other families that ate there that night who also got the wrong plates.Food: 3 starsPrice: 3 starsService: unmentionable.
Wonderful place in a great location.  I had the Mac & cheese with duck confit and it was to die for.  Good wine list and options.  Will be back next trip

This restaurant was wonderful. We started our New Year's Eve meal off with the beef tartar and escargot. It did not disappoint. For dinner we had the veal cheeks and duck while our friends had the hanger steak and lamb. Every dish was amazing and nothing was left by the end of the meal. To drink we had the house red which wasn't listed on the menu but was the perfect choice and paired well with the dishes.

My girlfriend and I came here and shared the goat cheese salad, the gazpacho soup of the day, and the braised lamb shank. It was all delicious--I became hungrier as I ate the food because it tasted so good! Along with that, the service was very friendly and it was really nice to sit outside and enjoy the setting of the restaurant.

Very cute restaurant, and they offer outdoor seating as well! My sister and I had come here for a late dinner (~9:30), so they had already run out of several options for main courses, including the lamb shank (which I had been eyeing), and the duck ravioli (which my sister had been contemplating). My sister ended up getting the beef tartare with a side of fries and salad, and I opted for the sea bass on a bed of quinoa, and we had the torchon de foie gras to start. They also serve complimentary bread !The foie gras was good, but we both haven't had foie gras often enough to tell whether it was amazing. The mains were both really good though! My sister really enjoyed her beef tartare, and my sea bass was delicious as well, and the quinoa was super flavorful. At the end of our meal, we were both stuffed, but decided to share a dessert. We got the pineapples with sugar on top, which was doused in rum. It was really cool, because our server, Simon, brought the rum to our table, and lit it on fire in front of us! Super super cool! Overall, it was a great dining experience - the food was really tasty, the service was really good and friendly, and I really like the outdoor patio! Will definitely come back again (at an earlier time) to try their other menu items!

What a delight. Started with the "discovery board" and was brought an array of prosciutto, salami, blue cheese, brie and other incredible delicacies. Then we had the French onion soup which dripped with flavorful expression and was a complete highlight. Finally we shared the duck (although we were full) we got recommended this dish from our server who voiced that guests travel to the restaurant for this particular dish. Despite being full we finished the entire dish of duck and wanted more! Service was attentive, helpful and charming while the location had an old school warmth to it. 10/10 recommend this spot for rich wine, romantic lighting and an evening one will never forget.

I visited this Montreal bistro in the dead of winter this past February and I can not understand how I over looked writing a review until now. Bistro's in general tend to prepare all the French classics and LDG is no exception. It was a frightfully cold snowy evening when I entered the restaurant, there was another party of five at a nearby table, I suppose the weather was a factor as it certainly was not the food I can assure you. I ordered the Lamb shank with paprika and Jack Daniels reduction, mashed potatoes, fresh brussel sprouts, carrots, green and red pepper. The lamb was what you would have expected, it was falling off the bone tender, bursting with flavor, enhanced by a subtle, yet perfectly flavorful Jack Daniels reduction. The vegetables were cooked nicely, firm in texture, each of the respective flavors were identifiable; the perfect medley to accompany the lamb shank. I have found over the years dining in Montreal the house wines are more than suitable as was the case here with their house red wine. For dessert I had Crème brûlée which, I must say, was excellent far better than many I've had here in the states and certainly the equal of what I have experienced in Europe. I ended the meal with a Tariquet Armagnac, a very good one which I thoroughly enjoyed as I gazed out the window on that wintery February evening. As I looked out the window, I reflected on what a pleasant experience it was dining at Les Deux Gamins from the service to the food and the traditional bistro atmosphere, one I hope to repeat very soon.

This is such a cute bistro on a cute street.  We stopped here for lunch and were surprised we were only one of three tables here, but they must attract a night/dinner crowd instead.Our waiter was very nice and attentive and spoke enough English to help us out.  My mom ordered a beer that she did not like and he was very willing to get her something else.Here's what we had:- White fish baked in foil - I forgot the exact name, but with the veggies and sauce, this was amazing.  The fish was moist and the sauce complimented the fish and veggies very well.- Veal liver - served with potatoes.  This was a beautiful dish with nicely cooked liver and tasty potatoes - mashed but still with the texture of potato chunks.   Our party actually ordered two of these specials, and our waiter came with one and told us one burned so the kitchen was making a replacement for my husband.  It was worth the wait and we appreciated the honesty.- Salmon tartar - my brother ordered this and I had a taste.  Overall well seasoned and the entree portion was a good size- apple tar tatin - I was a bit disappointed in this.  Although what came tasted good, it was more of a cold apple pie than the hot caramelized apple puff pastry that I expected.Next time we visit Montreal, I'll come back here for dinner!

Went there for dinner. The food was fantastic. Two of us shared French onion soup, risotto appetizer, and lamb shank. We had creme brulee for dessert, which was a bit of a disappointment (not as creamy as others brulees that I've had/made). We tried to use the yelp coupon for free dessert, and even though we showed/told the waitress ahead of ordering the dessert, she insisted on charging us for it. Besides the dessert fiasco, the service was good.

A Montreal must. Excellent food and very friendly staff and the prices are reasonable: we got the lamb shank and split a plate of risotto, which they split into two plates after we asked the staff. Beautiful atmosphere, feels like a little Paris in Montreal, so if you want a fancy French dinner you really don't need to go to the much more expensive ones in the Old Port. I also have to note that the portions are a good size, you won't get the tiny portions of a typical upscale restaurant. Highly recommend, this is now our go-to spot.

Great classic French bistro food in a great neighborhood.   I heard of this place some time ago, but never had the opportunity to stop by during one of my many trips to Montreal.  We took that walk over from our hotel on a rainy night and were greeted by the friendly staff and sat immediately.The starters were so-so - 3 start worthy on their own - but still tasty and enjoyable.  The gaspacho was fresh, but a bit too spicy for the two of us that had it.  The escargot (served in a cast iron pot) were tasty, but maybe a tad bit oily.  The bread served at the table is worthy of 5 stars, however, and is served with a great, fatty french butter.The mains were simply excellent.   Two of us had the beef bourguignon special of the week, which was some of the best B.B. that I've every tasted - it was simply amazing.  Another had the hanger steak frites, which was cooked perfectly.  Our other friend had a classic Salade Nicoise, which had large pieces of perfectly-grilled tuna.This is a cute place.  The atmosphere is great, the service is friendly and it has a great wine list.  Unfortunately, it was a cold and rainy spring day, but I can imagine that it's even better when its front garage door opens up onto the pedestrian street out front.

Unfortunately for us this was a miss. The only dish we enjoyed was the risotto. The french onion soup was fine, not the best we have had. The butternut squash soup was bland and under-seasoned. We requested steak well done, my daughter is 9 and just prefers it this way. The waitress was hesitant about it being cooked well done which honestly, a child should have a steak however he/she prefers so they eat it.  I also had the steak in a shallot sauce and parsnip puree. Again nothing special. Our waitress forgot our drinks after asking twice. We were disappointed as it has such good reviews.

Our first time here was a 4 star rating, however this visit we can only give a one star rating so overall I would say it's 2 stars.  The French onion soupWas burnt and our escargots was gritty - like eating sand.... And we returned all our escargots and the chef refused to take it off the bill.  This is poor customer service.  French bagettes were served but the portion was wanting.  Probably our last visit to this restaurant.  Sorry.
Waitress was nice, Duck confit was really good. However, maybe because it was Christmas Eve, but we waited for soups alone for almost an hour.......

The dorade was flavorless and dry.  The lamb was salty and dry.  The side dish of vegetables literally was six pieces of over cooked zucchini.  I don't understand all the good reviews. I stopped here for a quick meal on my way back to NY and it was truly the worse meal of the vacation. The best part of dinner were the group of young musicians playing on the corner. I can't recommend this place.  The dish was depressing.

Great little bistro in Montreal! We trekked across town in the snow to try it and left perfectly happy with our decision. Good service, great food and a charming/quaint atmosphere. We'd definitely come back next time we're in Montreal.

We ate in the plaza here on an seasonably balmy September night for Montreal. The menu was friendly and everyone's dish was delicious. The waiter was Charming and confident, something I always appreciate. The Mexican restaurant 100 feet away was celebrating an obscure Mexican holiday with music and dancing, so though the music was a little incongruous culturally it redoubled the sense of festivity.
this place is amazing! Found on Yelp and the onion soup/steak were unreal. also Isabella, our waitress, was awesome. Definitely recommend

First meal in Montreal with my husband during our visit, and we really liked the place. The day we visited was a busy night, and the service was slow, but the waiters were all very pleasant and nice, made things a lot better.Thumbs up for all the food we ordered. Foie gras, beef Tarte, duck, lamb shank and salmon, all very well cooked/prepared, and the portion was good too. I have to mention that they have good bread as well. Usually, a restaurant pays attention to basic things like bread/rice, they care, and if they care, they will always serve good food.If we are back to visit again, I'll come back to this place!

Fantastic value and great French bistro.After spending 4 days visiting Montreal, this was the only place I felt I had to review. The food, service and atmosphere was all great and it was really good value at $125 for 2 people with a bottle of wine and 3 courses each.I went on a Sunday night so it was basically empty during the whole 2 hour dinner. The French Onion Soup was really the highlight and worth going back for with the chocolate lava cake dessert a close second. The warm salad with honey, mac & cheese with duck confit and filtet mignon was all really solid. The house red was a merlot and great value at $18.

all dishes are good. And the waiter was very nice and helpful. We had all "xx of the day" and the taste is surprisingly good( duck is a little over cooked, but the source and artichoke are very good and creative).

Good food absolutely crappy service.  We didn't get the waiter to come by for half an hour.   We had to wait a half hour for drinks and bread after putting in  the order.   We had to ask,  after almost finishing dinner for two dishes.   Our waiter was so bad that two other waitresses had to step up and replenish bread,  water  and provide desert.   But he was very attentive when it came time to leave ands tip.  On to the food.   The food overall was good to very good,  with the gnocchi in a foie gras sauce outstanding, light fluffy with a satisfying foie gras flavor. I personally found some of the food to be slightly underseasoned, but the rest of my party thought things were ok. Salmon tartar was fresh and flavorful.  Foie gras was rich and well prepared.Easily a four star with a decent server.

We chose Les Deux Gamins for our date night due to the strong reviews on Yelp.  The restaurant is quite cozy and the atmosphere is casual.  We started the night with the French Onion Soup and the Escargot.  French Onion Soup was average but the Escargot was disappointing.  There was not much flavour to the dish.  We had the Beef Tartare and Duck Confit as our main course.  Beef Tartare and the accompanying salad was delicious, but the fries were soggy upon arrival.  The Duck Confit packed a lot of flavours but was a little dry.  The accompanying candied kumquat salad was a nice idea, but the whole salad lacked flavour except for the kumquat.  Overall, the restaurant is decent.  Wine prices are very reasonable and there's a good variety.  The service staffs are excellent and friendly.

Great service, very nice staff. We all loved the bread that was amazing crunchy outside soft inside. It suits salmon tartares and foie gras really well. The main courses we had a duck confit and a medium beef hanger steak pan fried were tasty. The mushrooms sautéed was flavorful.

Les Deux Gamins is a cozy bright restaurant that makes dining intimate but casual. The service was attentive and though we made no reservations, they didn't rush us since we came before 6pm. We had the duck confit and charcuterie/cheese plate. Really loved the split pea mash/puree with the duck, and the charcuterie platter had a variety of meats cheeses and pickles. We had creme brulee for dessert; though it was creamy and the texture was good, the top was too thick for our preference, and it was not consistently "carameled". There were lots of chunky white sugar that they missed when they torched the topping.
This is one of my go to French restaurants in town. The decor will remind you of a Paris bistro and the food is absolutely amazing! I highly recommend the lamb.

This was our second time at Les Deux Gamins - we always try to include one French place on our trip.  Food-wise, the experience was consistent with last time.  This time around, I got the foie gras to start, and lamb shank for main dish - she got the goat cheese salad and steak.  Most notably, they give very large portions here for French cuisine (which is a good thing, some places sacrifice substance for presentation) - I was completely stuffed by lamb at the end of the meal.  The meat was also very tender, especially for lamb which can be tough at some places.  I think they could downsize the meat and upsize the accompaniment a bit, but really just a minor complaint.Service wise everyone was very friendly.  I do have to say, it was a 100% different experience coming here in the summer vs the winter.  In the winter we were probably 1 of 4 couples in the entire place, seated by a cozy fire.  In the summer this time around, the place was jammed pack, and even with a reservation we got seated indoors (there is a large outdoor area).  However, we were still close to the window and most importantly, the service didn't seem to suffer too much from this. Great place overall.
all of the food from the bread to the charcuterie board to the prime rib for 3 were amazing. also really nice to sit outside.

Came up from NYC for a bachelorette party ! They were so kind and let us do a pre-fixed menu which just made life so much easier for all of us instead of having to select from a million things on their menu. Everything was good - some didn't like their beat soup (very bland) and others didn't like their fish. But, to each their own. Their duck was PHENOMENAL. The staff was also very attentive and cared for us. They also let us sit in the restaurant as they were cleaning (until 1130pm). Great time !

Got the lamb shank after seeing all the yelp reviews and was not disappointed. The meat fell right off the bone! I was expecting a little more flavor, but I haven't had many lamb shanks to say how this compares. Friends got the steak, veggie pasta, and duck confit and said that all were very good.
Perfect Bistro with a friendly and cozy ambiance and great food!! We made a reservation and had no problem getting to our show on time!

We came here after all of the great yelp reviews. Thank you all for recommending this place to us. Eats:- special of the day Baked Pork with mashed potatoes.....delicious and just a juicy piece of pork- lamb shank which was fall off the bone soft and very tasty- French onion soup also very delicious with the right amount of onions and cheese. Not so salty as compared to French onions soups you would find in the statesLikes:- service was very good. Our waitress was friendly and on point with every request- food was good- the house baguette was good- atmosphere - yelp complementary dessert with a check in!!!!Dislikes:- tables are a bit small- complementary dessert had a burned shell on the creme brûlée
They do their best.  Little pricey for what you get.  The servers are super nice.  But unfortunately the quality just wasn't there.

We had escargot and fois gras for apps and the fois gras gnocchi and lamb shank for mains. All were delicious, especially the gnocchi. Service could be better,particularly from one waiter dressed in a suit. He had a shitty attitude.

Turned us away at 920pm. They closed early. They kind of ruined our dinner after travelling all day. Now it's too late to find anywhere else. Really horrible businesses practice. I could see closing ten or fifteen minutes early, but nearly an hour when you have potential customers in your doorway?Amateur hour. Don't waste your time, you'll end up eating sandwiches at 930 pm because they screwed you by closing early with a smile and a shrug.

I came here with a large group of friends (10) so it was a good idea to book a reservation ahead of time. The waitress was extremely courteous. The restaurant gives off a very cozy vibe, with a patio. I had ordered escargot and pastry and the steak tartare. My friend across from me ordered the foie gras with figs and duck confit. Let's start with the escargot. It was amazing! I love how the flavour of the dish isn't taken away by the sauce. The steak tartare was also really good. My friends foie gras was pretty rich in flavour and as for the duck confit - he liked very much. Portion sizes are surprisingly decent...I couldn't finish everything. I would have tried the creme brulee - If I wasn't so stuffed! Overall this place has it all. Great food. Great environment. Great service. Would definitely recommend.
Very cozy French restaurant, it has nice view and atmosphere in the summer time! The food is good too, but avoid risotto, not too good tho.

Came here on our last night at Montreal and so glad we did. The service was great even though there were only 2 waitress working. First time having French and this set a pretty high standard. Foi Gras was like meaty ice cream. Escargot was well seasoned and tender. The Duck Confit was fall off the bone and the hangar steak was a perfectly cooked medium rare. For dessert, highly recommend the chocolate brownie. Overall great experience with great food.
Wonderful onion soup, lamb shank with purer parsnip and carrots.  Reasonable and wonderful.
Great service, amazing food! The French onion soup, duck confit and hanger were outstanding!
Quiet French restaurant probably will be admired by someone who loves French cuisine.   The food was OK,  quite pricey, nothing special about the ambience and actually it was extremely cold
A casual and delicious spot on the Plateau. Try to sit outside!

Wonderful meal! The food was delicious, especially the French onion soup and goat cheese salad. Our server Ben was fantastic and gave us some extra fresh bread for my leftover goat cheese and a yummy yelp dessert. The restaurant's atmosphere is very special and there is even a large lovely terrace to sit out on at night. 5 stars for the excellent food and service.
Wonderful food and atmosphere!  Excellent service.  We came very late and they kept the kitchen open for us.  Ingredients seemed very fresh.

The prices knocked us back a bit, but the flavors were worth it. I fell in love with something simple as the fried scalloped potatoes (largely because of the duck fat), and the charcuterie plate was standard but good. We all raved about the house red wine, which is quite a deal at $20/bottle, and came out to about two glasses each.It was charming, and felt just like a real French bistro, with tables spilling out onto the cobblestoned street. They were very accommodating, though we walked in forty minutes before closing.

We ordered beef tartare, duck confit and braised lamb shank as recommended by the waiter and they were all so delicious! The restaurant was quite busy when we were there, but the waiter did try his best to pay attention to all of us and provide great service. Would totally recommend this place ~~

One of the few French restaurants open on a Monday. That said they were certainly not ready for a large group of tourists to show up! Food took forever, and the waiter did his best to accommodate us although he probably understood about 60% of my English. Can't argue with the quality of the food though. Everybody left happily satisfied with their meal despite the long wait times. Will hope to come back on a future visit!

My boyfriend and I came here for dinner during our vacation to Montreal.  We were hoping for some great French cuisine, and Les Deux Gamins did not disappoint.  Delicious, delicious food.  I am a vegetarian, and though there were no meat-free entrees on the menu, the chef personally offered to create a vegetarian dish for me.  Our waiter was knowledgeable about the menu and wine selection, and helped us suggest the right wine to accompany our meal.Next time we are in Montreal, we will definitely go back to Les Deux Gamins!

A great restaurant experience in all. Recommend the front outdoor seating, complete with a few nearby street musicians (typically it seems), and the pocket Euro'ish atmosphere. Very satisfied with the  charcuterie, foie gras, and house bread in our first course. Lamb shank entree was great, as others here have noted. We were indifferent toward the sea bass. And for dessert, can't go wrong with a creme brûlée; and though I'm not usually a cheesecake fan, we enjoyed their version very much.

Perfection! Everything from the bread to the French onion soup was delicious. Filet mignon was cooked perfectly and the potatoes au gratin was the best I've ever had! Also sampled the duck and lamb which were amazing as well. Really can't go wrong with anything you order here. The crème brulé was yummy as well. The food here was amazing. Highly recommend coming for dinner. The only down side was we waited quite a while to order once we sat down and had to ask for bread after we got our apps. Other than that all the food came out perfectly spaced so we had time to digest between courses.Overall perfection! Amazing food , adorable layout inside as well. Nice atmosphere.

Perhaps it is the hype from all the reviews, or how hungry I was, or how beautifully the food was displayed, but I was not wow'ed the way I thought I would be. The food was enjoyable and the service was nice. I particularly enjoyed the escargot and the ceme brulee (despite it's thicker than expected crust). The portions are rather large, so come hungry! The service is good, and it helps to have a reservation. Prices are quite reasonable.

If you are visiting Montreal because you are hoping it is a bit of France in North America, you Must Go Here. Everything we had here was wonderful. For appetizers, the beef tartare and foie gras. Duck confit and lamb shank were exquisite. The hanger steak was amazingly tender and one of the best pieces of beef I have ever eaten.  The service was good. It's in the Latin Quarter, so rich in ambience. We dined out in the street as the sun set. All in all a perfect evening and it made us glad we had come to Montreal.
The restaurant is nice! The foods are delicious and owner and staffs are so kind. I love here's onion soup. Absolutely I'll go there again.

Good wine list, which is not a difficult thing to do in Montreal.First course--torchon de foie gras, nicely done.Mesclun salads were fresh.Main course--where it counts--we swear that the "monkfish" special was sea bass.  Not bad, but not great.  False advertising, in my opinion.Confit de Canard was old, tired, and had skin the consistency of a limp dishrag, not crispy as it should be.  Server asked how it was, and I complained.  No acknowledgement of the complaint, not even a slight apology.  By the way, I did NOT finish my plate, which is rare.  What is the purpose of asking the customer how dinner is, if nothing is done?We did not bother with dessert after that.  My opinion is that you should not bother with this restaurant.  I imagine that my opinion will not matter, though, because they are in a good location, and attract plenty of business.  We will not be dining here on our next visit to Montreal.
Visiting from Toronto.  Amazing restaurant - delicious - will go back.  We had the charcuterie platter, duck and lamb with fresh bread.  All were worth repeating.  Classic French cuisine.

Big props to this place for offering some great French fare for a more affordable price than you usually see! I got the French Onion Soup to start and it was incredible. Duck ravioli as an entree was nothing particularly special to me, but my boyfriend thought it was outstanding. He got the steak frites which was great as well.Service was a little cool...I kind of felt like I was dealing with the stereotypical French waiter that you feel like can't actually exist.I ate in their outdoor patio area which was beautiful in the spring. The whole area is very cute and so I would definitely recommend doing that if possible!

Such friendly staff! My vegan friend couldn't eat anything off their menu, but the chef made something on the spot for her and explained all the ingredients he used. She loved it.I had the French onion soup, which had great cheese but was otherwise not spectacular. However, I ordered the duck leg confit for a main and didn't at all expect two whole duck legs on my plate -- the portions are huge and the food was absolutely delicious!

What a gem! This was the exact place I wanted to go with outdoor seating. Not really a big fan to dine with other tourists in Old Montreal during the Grand Prix weekend, I found this place on a side street near Saint Laurent and it did not disappoint. The French onion soup was perfect -  not too cheesy but perfect you could taste the great combination of cheese and onion it was that good. I ordered the duck confit as my entree it was cooked perfectly. The duck was very juicy and the meat was silky smooth. Pairing the food with a glass of Kronenbourg was surely a winner. I finished off with a creme burlee (hazelnut) and a cup of cappuccino. Unfortunately I have to deduct a star here for very slow service near the end of my meal. I had to wait for a long time for my cappuccino and then my bill but if I am back in town, I would love to visit again.
Food was really good. Service was great.  We ordered the foie gras twice and lamb shank.  The gazpacho soup of the day was delicious and refreshing.

Ordered the Morue/cod. The service was kinda slow which is not a problem with me if the food is good, but sadly that was not the experience I had. The fish was not well cooked it was very heavy (not in a good steaky fish kind of way) and somewhat dry, and the flavor was not good either. It had a kind of bland and greasy taste that was okay at the beginning but by the end was grossing me out. It also had a bunch of seeds and nuts stuck on the top of the piece of fish which I found didn't pair with the fish very well. I tryed to appreciate it, but I couldnt understand the reason for pairing those two flavors. The one redeeming part of the dish was that it came with some very tasty carrots and I'm not usually a huge fan of those. A family member of mine had the duck confit and it was alright, but not great. Finally our server was very attentive and kind, but for the price tag that comes with the mediocre food I can't recommend this restaurant.

A lovely meal with delicious food and outstanding service. Standouts were the salmon tartare and country terrine appetizers, the lamb shank, tagliatelle, and beef tartare. Very relaxing atmosphere, with the front wall opened to the elements (outdoor seating is also available, but we were worried about the rain). If you're here for the jazz festival, think about coming up Rue Saint-Laurent to escape from the chaos for a bit and enjoy a great casual meal in a pleasant environment.

Bottom line: Delicious food, OK service. The restaurant has a very distinctive decor, surprisingly old-school non-hipster vibe and offers absolutely amazing food. We had our reservation at 7.30, we were seated right away. However we spend almost 2.5 hours in the restaurant from  Appetizers to Desert. However the chef was nice enough to cook us up a delicious 50oz flank steak for the same price of the 30oz that we ordered. If any body is looking for an affordable, but delicious french food this is the place to be.

Wow. I made reservations and went here with my friend on Saturday evening and was very pleased with my choice.The interior is very intimate and romantic and old style, with Victorian hex tiles on the floor of the main part where we were sitting looking out to the street from the garage pane windows.  We ordered escargot to share, my friend had the lamb shank for her main, and I had the duck confit with a glass of the Minervois region red. The escargots were excellent as the sauce, which was likely some red wine reduction, had a lot of flavour with entire cloves of garlic and diced tomatoes. The lamb was tender, as was the duck, but the parsnip mash was particularly good, and stood out in my mind. I preferred the lamb, but my friend preferred the duck because it retained the duck flavour well, so I guess it's a matter of personal preference, but needless to say, we enjoyed both the mains. As a note, the red was full bodied, not particularly dry, and went nicely with the duck.For dessert, we shared a creme brulee, for which the custard was not overly egg-y or sweet, though I found it a little odd that the custard was cold when served. I am used to having it at room temperature. Nonetheless, the flavour was good, and the portion generous.The service was probably what put me over the top for this place. We had a main male server (I wish I knew his name...) and a female server to assist on the side. They were the right amounts of attentive, and very, very professional and kind. I am always a bit apprehensive about going to French restaurants when I am only able to speak English, because sometimes I get poor service on account of my language. Both our servers were friendly and attentive, and the guy even gave us dessert on the house! Terrific dining experience.

Perhaps the best dinner we had while in Montreal and it was on the last day.Started the meal with the foie gras terrine served over toasted country bread.  This was good but I think the foie gras that I had at Animal in LA was much better.  Probably wouldn't order this if I came back to Montreal.  We also tried the french onion soup.  I loved it.  It had a little sweet taste to it.  There was the perfect amount of onions and the cheese was perfectly melted on top.  Delicious!  For the main meal my girlfriend and I split the filet mignon with potatoes forestière and foie gras sauce.  This was awesome.  It is a very heavy dish with steak, potatoes, pearl onions and nice cuts of sliced bacon.  I scarfed the whole thing down while my girlfriend watched because she had was so full.  The restaurant staff is great.  They are very attentive and took care of the clientele that was eating at the restaurant from my observations.  At the end of the meal they even brought out a shot for my lady and I.  It was some schnapps (probably apple).  Thank you for the kind gesture.  And by the end of the meal the locals were playing in the fountain that was across from the restaurant.  Someone had thrown some bubbles in and the fountain had turned into a bubble extravaganza.  Awesome!!I am sure that this restaurant does well since it was packed outside and it was almost 10:30pm at night on a warm summer Sunday evening.Cheers!

This is a very classic French bistro but with very elevated food. The French onion soup was everything you hope that dish is going to be. We then had the Gardener's Harvest and the Duck confit. Both dishes were knock you on your ass fantastic. Together, they were a truly memorable experience. Add to that the excellent, friendly service and a great (low markup) wine list and I can't recommend this place highly enough. Run, don't walk.

This is a great place, especially for a romantic dinner with a loved one. Quiet atmosphere, helpful staff, and delicious food made this restaurant the newest addition in my list of places I want to go back to. Slight cons: the waiters were slightly distracted at times, which wasn't very professional in my opinion, and the tables were a bit close to one another, which can get uncomfortable, especially if your fellow diners are loud or unpleasant in any way.Altogether though, I heartily recommend this place.

Meh....lamb shank dry needed sauce, mashed taters too glue like, roasted potaoes some hard and some soft, duck confit good, cod great, French onion soup decent. Waiting forever to get check and leave unforgivable

Our meal here was definitely not what we were expected. The Good:-The lamb shank was excellent (5/5)- soft, tender, full of flavour-The waiter explained all our options thoroughly so we knew all of our menu choices-The community this restaurant is situated in is very cute and made for a good walk after the mealThe Bad:-We waited for an hour for our meal...our waiter only offered us bread AFTER we received our meal..really!? -The french onion soup was very, very salty- I couldn't even finish mine!-One member from our party got diarrhea from their Mussels (Daily special)We won't be back.

Wonderful bistro! Had a great dining experience - the staff make you feel at ease the whole time, and know when to approach you to take care of your dinning needs. The appetizer and main course menu are just the right size so as not to confuse the guests, and the wine list is wonderful. They also offer three types of locally brewed beer on tap (Griffon - great craft brewery in Montreal), which can be paired with all the fair on the menu. We started with the French onion soup, which was done to perfection, and the adventure board, which was a variety of cheese, smoked duck with greens, a cup of pickled vegetables, prosciutto, salami, French Brie and Cheddar, with wonderful bread. For the mains we had lamb shank done to perfection (paired with the house merlot) and the hanger steak with green salad and potatoes (paired with the Griffon amber ale). It was all amazing. I highly recommend trying Les Deux Gamins if you're in the area - you won't be disappointed.

This is a hidden gem in Montreal. The ambience was delightful. The food we ordered was absolutely amazing. I had the French onion soup and chef's salad, my husband had the hangar steak and our daughter had escargot. We were all very pleased with the meals. The soup was the best I've ever had, the steak was cooked to perfection and the escargot scrumptious. Topped it off with delicious creme brûlée for dessert. Don't miss asking for Ben - the wait person who expertly managed the entire three floors of tables single handedly without missing a beat. Very charming as well!
The restaurant reminded me paris, environment is divine! Escargot was yummy! Duck confit was a bit dry ... But all the dishes were very tasty.

Wow. We were seated upstairs and then ended up leaving because I guess they forgot about us. Hard to believe as they weren't super busy. I have to say we were very disappointed as my wife was looking forward to trying the tartare. Even when we got up and left no one seem to notice. The one star is not a reflection of the food but because I am forced to give a rating. Disappointed.

We wanted a traditional French Canadian meal and we followed the positive reviews on Yelp to Les Deux Gamins, which served us a super romantic, cozy meal.  It was a Sunday night and the weather was horrific (freezing cold, ice everywhere) so Les Deux Gamin was very empty compared to how other reviewers described it.  I would recommend going on Sunday- the tourists have mostly gone home!  We were seated right next to the fireplace which was really cute and nice and warm.  We basically ordered the richest things on the menu- French onion soup, steak frites, and the most incredible macaroni and cheeese with duck confit.  Seriously, I cannot say enough about this mac and cheese.  It was rich and luxurious and the duck confit was dry and salty and contrasted so well with the creaminess of the cheese.  They paced our dishes well and we had a really nice fireside meal.  They had a Yelp deal for a free dessert but the creme brulee was just ok.  It was more like a chunky pudding and had been bruleed earlier and refrigerated so the top was not warm or crisp anymore.  The flavor was good but we honestly should probably just have skipped it altogether after dinner.  Overall we really enjoyed our meal at Les Deux Gamins and I would probably travel to Montreal again just to have the mac and cheese with duck confit.

I though this place was excellent. The head waiter Ben really made sure we had a great time. He is really an excellent manager. We got the stew which was amazing and the duck confit which was also pretty good. I really recommend this place for a casual tourist stopping by Montreal. This place does get a little packed around 9. The prices are average not more or less than in any other French place in the area.

Loved this restaurant, located in a very interesting neighborhood, The space was nicely decorated and we sat upstairs next to an open front looking out over the street.  Benoit was a warm and friendly host who sat us within minutes of our arrival.  The food was phenomenal and pricing was very reasonable given the quality of the meal.  Service was impeccable.  We ate there Friday night and contemplated going back Saturday, but since we were in town for only the weekend decided to try another place.  We all wish we did go back!

We had a wonderful experience at this restaurant. Our server was amazing and helped us find a bottle of wine that the entire table liked. She even suggested an appetizer that wasn't on the menu. We would go back there all the time!
The service and food were excellent. The decor and ambiance were cozy and inviting. I highly recommend the hanger steak and French onion soup - absolutely delicious.

We ordered fillet mignon and duck confit. Service was very good, although our food took some time to come out. Fillet mignon was very tasteless and chewy. Duck was too dry and a bit smelly. My guess is they used frozen meat. In my opinion, the food here is not very good considering its price tags.

We ate here when visiting for the grand prix. Being from Wisconsin, we don't get a lot of French food. Now I don't really know how authentic any of this was, but that isn't the point. The food is absolutely amazing and the atmosphere both inside and out is very classy. I had the duck shepard's pie. Furthermore, my expectations of service in a French-speaking area were pretty low. But the server definitely impressed and now I leave my stereotypes at the door. Call in advance for a table because this place was crazy busy on a Saturday night!

We were staying nearby and stopped in on a whim. The service is extremely friendly and the food was excellent. The terrine was the best I've ever had!  The bread is delicious and plentiful and the planche de decouvert was the perfect snacking appetizer with wine. Would highly recommend. In fact we came back the next day for more!

I came here for a birthday dinner, choosing this spot because it was open on a Sunday night. I wasn't sure how it would go. The latest reviews here in English seemed good, but the French ones were terrible. For a French restaurant, I'd tend to give the latter more weight, but I remained openminded.The staff were very friendly and helpful, but there were just too many mistakes to be forgiven. Unfortunately for us, the menu was about to be changed the next day, so about three items were off. But the server neglected to tell us about the specials - mussels. I wouldn't have ordered them anyway, but it was a bit strange to realise that I could have, by seeing servers bring back the pots. Service was prompt but forgetful. We had no place settings when our starters arrived. We had to ask twice for Worcestershire sauce for the tartare, and our water was empty more than once. To be fair, there was a large party of about 12 on the terrace, but given the Indian Summer weekend we were having, and the resto's location on Prince Arthur, they should have had more staff.We were three and ordered a goat's cheese salad and two lots of snails in puff pastry to start:- The snails came in a cheese sauce with two triangles of puff pastry on the side. That isn't a feuilleté. Also, the cheese sauce "manquait de finesse" - was not terribly refined. I wouldn't say it was disgusting; it was actually reasonably tasty, particularly as the snails were quite juicy, but it was very disappointing, with the cheese sauce completely overwhelming the dish.- The goat's cheese salad was also not really "dans les règles de l'art" - how it's usually done. It The salad looked like it was for decoration, which shouldn't be the case at all. There should be a subtle combination of salad leaves and cheese on small slices of bread.For mains, we ordered two plates of duck confit, which was billed as "forestier" ( with mushrooms), accompanied by roasted vegetables and potatoes. The other member of our party ordered the steak tartare, which he was very pleased to be able to mix himself. Except that he had to wait for the Worcestershire sauce. The tartare was accompanied by fries and salad, and wasn't bad.The duck confit on the other hand was extremely disappointing. A leg of duck confit should be crispy on the outside and melt in the mouth when you bite into it. It wasn't. In terms of portions, it was great - there were two legs. But the skin wasn't at all crispy, and it was extremely salty. I was tempted to send it back but contented myself with simply letting the server know. On top of that, it was accompanied by one half of a large button mushroom (forestier, you say?), some difficult-to-identify "roasted" vegetables (blackened on the outside but crunchy - seeming to indicate they'd been cooked in a too-hot oven, too quickly), and what I can only describe as "breakfast potatoes".For dessert, we had two crème brûlées and a brownie. They were both pretty good, but the crème brûlée was taken straight out of the fridge. It should be served "tiède" - at least at room temperature, and possibly ever-so-slightly warm.The place has just changed hands apparently, so one might expect teething problems. However, I don't think I can give them a second chance unfortunately.

We came across Les Deux Gamins through a yelp recommendation and I have to say my SO and I had such a wonderful time!  The food was SOO delicious and service was spot on.We ordered the French Onion soup which was the best french onion soup I have had in North America.  It was very close to my French Onion soup experience in Paris.  We shared a salmon tartare which was light and flavourful.  It was like sashmi done right, French styles.Their creme brule was devine!  Rich yet light, I am glad I was sharing the dessert.Les Deux Gamins will be on the visit list when I am back in Montreal in the future.

I ate here on my last night in Montreal, as I wanted to try an authentic French-Canadian meal that wasn't too expensive like some of the other ones in the city. I was impressed not only by the reviews I had read, but also by their use of OpenTable and the Yelp offer for the free dessert.The restaurant itself has a romantic, cute-ish ambience that would be really nice for a date. I got the french onion soup as an appetizer, which was pretty amazing - definitely worth getting. For my main course, I tried the duck confit mac & cheese. This was also really good, but also really rich - I couldn't finish it and had to take it home. I checked in on Yelp to get a free creme brulee, which I thought was quite good as well.My only criticism is that it took a while for the food to come, and it was a Monday night so the restaurant was pretty empty. However, all in all, I definitely recommend the restaurant.

We got the foie gras, lamb shank, and bass. The food  was delicious and the service was fantastic. Finished everything on the plate. The lamb was so so tender and came right off the bones. The fish was done nicely. The drinks were strong:). Total bill for 2 people including 4 drinks was $150. Worth it I think!

Had Beef Tartare, Duck Confit and Creme Brulee. Can't say I was disappointed. Everything was delicious , rich and full of flavor! Ambiance is great especially for a date or girls night out. Servers are very friendly and make the experience great.

We flew into Montreal late, ended up lugging our luggage up snow covered streets for a few blocks, and finally realized we really were hungry.  Looking around, we found this place here on Yelp, and decided this was the place to go.  I called up, and even tho' we were 30 minutes from the last serving, they gladly took our reservation and we headed out (taxi to the restaurant got us there just past 10).  We ordered a few different things, including the snails, the duck confit, and a nice bottle of wine.  Honestly, I can't imagine any choices coming out bad (except maybe for onion soup - those of you who've read my other reviews know I dislike onions gross) - BUT if you're into that kind of ingredient, I'm sure they do a stellar job with that too.    The staff was friendly and bilingual (thank goodness, rusty french + travel exhaustion = "ou est la biblioteuqe?"), and overall an incredibly pleasant experience. I would definitely recommend and go back here the next time I'm in Montreal.Side note: I've updated this review to clarify a few things (like my personal distaste for onions is in no means a reason to not go here - LOL), so I'm also going to do two things - update the stars, having remembered that that our server did go out of her way to answer a few extra questions about non-restaurant related things to two out-of-towners, and also because the interior decor was also a treat to the eyes (next time I'd like to sit in one of the other floors to take in even more of it!)

2 adults and 2 teens visited Montreal for the first time and stumbled upon this nice french restaurant.  Everything we ordered was excellent.  The french onion soup was the best that we ever had at all of our experience of french cuisine so far.  The butchers cut was excellent, unbelievably flavorful, juicy, and hearty.  Between the four of us, we almost did not finish it because it was huge.  The duck confit was tender.  Just so yummy away from home.

I really enjoyed this place. The outdoor seating is great and our waiter was very friendly and attentive.We shared the French onion soup, it was excellent. And we also shared the large warm goat cheese salad, also fantastic. The goat cheese is thickly spread in a thin piece of bread that has been lightly drizzled with honey vinegar. Delicious.Highly recommended.

My fiancé and I were in Montreal for a few days and we spent our last night at Lea Deux Gamins. We ordered the French onion soup, hangar steak and duck confit. We also ordered a bottle of red wine that was recommended by the server. The wine was delicious! The food on the other hand was just totally ok. My steak was a little over cooked and my fiancé's duck was a little dry. All of the sides to our dishes and the soup were great. Why give this place 4 stars? We sat outside and it was awesome people watching. The service was spot on, attentive, quick, but not overbearing. We really enjoyed our last night, and this place was overall a great romantic date! A few tweaks would make it a 5/5.
This place is incredible! My brother and I got and split all their appetizers. All were amazing! Their melted goat cheese was delicious!!

For our last dinner in Montreal, we wanted to go for some authentic, delicious French food that wouldn't break the bank.
